content.text: Several tweets focused on AI agents and the elizaOS ecosystem. @dankvr highlighted a major use case for agents: pulling together disparate information sources, cleaning/enriching data, and converting it to interoperable formats for faster answers and reports. He emphasized the importance of data hygiene, organizing and labeling data, and preparing for autonomous agents. @elizaOS announced that cutting-edge agent systems are being built with elizaOS and invited users to apply for their ecosystem tester program, with only 50 spaces available in this exclusive community. @shawmakesmagic mentioned that they're working on useful agent roadmaps and eventually a 'super agent' where 'Eliza will be a real girl.' He also noted that he hasn't seen other major framework teams reach the level of problems they're tackling with agents, suggesting that those who think agents are easy might not fully understand the complexity.

@shawmakesmagic shared updates about a 3D world AI agents project being built on Hyperfy, an open source 3D world engine. He announced that they've got it working now, with agents connecting to the world by default. The Hyperfy platform supports apps with interfaces that agents can use, allowing them to pick up items, navigate the world, and emote. He noted there's been a lot of positive response to the 3D world agents concept, though he acknowledged they are 'very much a shiny toy' while other agents they're building are more useful. He suggested that seeing an MMO of agents battling for a prize could have good viral potential and asked if they should coordinate in a Discord server or group chat.

@shawmakesmagic shared his experience with AR glasses, posting that he 'got Eliza on my face' by streaming microphone input to a server and text into Even Realities G1 glasses. He described the glasses as being as light as his regular glasses and mentioned that while the current setup is cool, 'the killer feature would be a camera.' He noted that he has an Xreal kit with AR and cameras coming in the mail. He chose the Even Realities G1 over Ray-Ban glasses because the latter lacked an SDK, though he mentioned that his current glasses also lack an SDK and use pure BLE communication. He promised to share the code when it's 'less ugly.'

Several tweets highlighted recent advancements in AI-generated video and animation. @shawmakesmagic retweeted @jen_w1n who claimed that by the end of the year, most short-form content on platforms like TikTok will probably be AI-generated, sharing a 100% AI-generated video made with Veo 3. @shawmakesmagic also retweeted @EHuanglu who showcased Meshy AI's ability to auto-rig and animate 3D characters in seconds with smooth movements. @shawmakesmagic retweeted @kalomaze who shared a Veo 3 video of 'hatsune miku plays minecraft on stream and shows off the statue she built of lebron james.' @shawmakesmagic retweeted @nmatares who tested prompt adherence with Veo 3 using a prompt about a dachshund running through a living room. @shawmakesmagic also retweeted @MustStopMurad who shared a video about 'Why AI is coming for your Job.'

@shawmakesmagic retweeted @AshConnell who demonstrated impressive 3D graphics performance on mobile devices. The demonstration featured 300 completely unique meshes (each with approximately 2,000 triangles), each with a unique 512x512 texture, cloned 5 times and placed randomly for a total of 1,800 objects. This impressive graphical performance was running on a 5-year-old iPhone 12 Pro, showcasing the capabilities of modern mobile devices for complex 3D rendering.

@shawmakesmagic shared his experience with Codex, noting that while he doesn't find the code quality to be very good and the web app is buggy on his phone, 'the overall experience of coding in bed is fucking incredible.' He later reported that Codex 'one-shotted a delete message + delete all messages feature in the GUI, complete with the backend routes,' but also mentioned that none of the four Codex tasks he started the previous night created a working pull request, so he restarted them on Jules. He also retweeted @zjasper666 who discussed GPU infrastructure for AI development, noting that '$1/hr h100s continues to be an insane deal.' @shawmakesmagic predicted that 'the average dev will spend more on AI than food and rent combined within 5 years.'

@shawmakesmagic retweeted @MarkBeylin who reminded followers that @BoostVC is actively writing $50k checks to builders at the earliest stages, encouraging those thinking of leaving boring jobs who need funding for experiments to apply. @shawmakesmagic also shared thoughts on investment models, suggesting that 'instead of projects we could just have a way to invest in founders and devs' since developers often have longer careers than their projects and may miss many times before succeeding. He noted that in VC, they say 'we invest in people' because they're building long-term relationships and understand that companies often pivot. He suggested there's space for this concept to be developed further, possibly leading to 'an era of decentralized Medicis.' He also announced plans to do 'Based Demo Day on May 31' with @nickcryptopro, inviting those building with elizaOS on Base to comment with their projects.

Several tweets contained humorous observations about AI. @shawmakesmagic retweeted @adonis_singh who compared Gemini to 'the kid that people bullied in high school and is now jacked, a millionaire and practices gratitude.' @shawmakesmagic also retweeted @creatine_cycle who joked that 'founding engineers be like "my job is really stressful but at least the pay is bad".' @shawmakesmagic shared a strange interaction with Grok AI that appeared to reference virtual strip clubs with AI agents, responding simply with 'What.' @shawmakesmagic also retweeted @Josh_XT who stated 'Complaining about a problem without posing a solution is called whining.'

@shawmakesmagic retweeted @girl_intheverse who shared a product development insight: 'Nobody cares about your product. They care about what it does for them.' This reflects a customer-centric approach to product development that focuses on benefits rather than features. @shawmakesmagic also shared his own productivity philosophy, tweeting 'You can do 50-100 incredible things in your life, But ONLY if you do them one after the other,' emphasizing the importance of focus and sequential achievement rather than attempting to do everything simultaneously.

@shawmakesmagic retweeted @viktor_vrp who shared a 'Repeatability test 3' video demonstrating robotic precision, described as 'pushing the limits.' The video shows a robotic system performing complex gripping and handling tasks, with the frame moving from a holder to a random spot on a table and back, without using a model to compensate for errors. This highlights advancements in robotics and automation technology.

Recent completed items in the elizaOS/eliza repository include several new features, bug fixes, test improvements, and other changes:

New Features:
- Added API endpoint for creating new rooms (PR #4647)
- Created world API endpoints (PR #4667)
- Added a 30-second timeout to registry parsing (PR #4678)
- Added CHANNEL_IDS to discord_plugin (PR #4665)
- Added Sentry logging to core logger errors (PR #4650)

Bug Fixes:
- Fixed shortcut reply to only work when no dynamic provider is present (PR #4670)
- Fixed reply action that was skipping dynamic providers (PR #4651)
- Fixed bats test flakiness (PR #4663)
- Fixed agent tests (PR #4661)
- Fixed sharp installation in CI that was causing integration tests to fail (PR #4654)
- Updated project starter character and fixed path for core package (PR #4671)

Test Improvements:
- Updated documentation, README, and tests for all CLI commands (PR #4646)
- Restored local AI test (PR #4676)
- Removed mock tests for CLI (PR #4674)
- Created cleaner, more readable test files (PR #4660)

Other Changes:
- Removed Twitter plugin (PR #4669)
- Removed global environment support (PR #4666)
- Attempted dev command tear down (PR #4664)
- Changed PGLite default directory (PR #4656)
- Improved Sentry defaults (PR #4655)
- Generalized Eliza agent character (PR #4653)
- Added Fly.io Docker deploy action for dev agent (PR #4652)

Four pull requests have been submitted to the elizaOS/eliza repository. PR #4672 by crypto-cooker addresses a fix for an undefined EchoChambersPlugin issue. PR #4660 by wtfsayo aims to create cleaner readable test files. PR #4661, also by wtfsayo, fixes agent tests. PR #4650 by ChristopherTrimboli adds Sentry logging functionality to core logger errors.

From May 20-21, 2025, the GitHub repository elizaos/eliza saw significant activity with 29 new pull requests, of which 22 were merged. There were no new issues reported during this period. The repository had 17 active contributors working on it.

The source provides information about the top contributors for the elizaOS/eliza GitHub repository. However, no specific details about the contributors or their contributions are provided in the source text.
